Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project includes significant advances in societal goals on energy security, sustainability, low cost energy, and reduced greenhouse gas emissions. The convection battery is a systemic approach to improve the way normal (not flow) battery chemistries are used in large systems (>2 kWh). This technology will make batteries lower cost and lower weight. Specific examples of how this technology can achieve these goals include: a) reducing the cost of a battery pack for an electric vehicle from $10,000 to $2,000, b) reducing the cost of using wind power by up to $0.05 per kWh, and c) lowering the cost of remote power system used on farms and regions without an electrical power grid. From a commercial perspective, the proposed technology will better enable several important industries such as wind power, electric vehicles, solar power, storage of grid electricity, and electrical power systems for remote locations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This Phase I SBIR project focused on further development and scale-up of a convection battery. A convection battery is a battery that uses pumped electrolyte to reduce concentration gradients within the electrode leading to improved performances. This is different than a redox flow battery that uses two electrolytes and an ion-exchange membrane separator, but rather the convection battery is capable of utilizing any standard diffusion chemistries such as Zinc-Alkaline and Lithium-Ion as the electrolyte is pumped through flow-permeable electrodes and separators.

                The major results of this project were twofold: the development of a scaled-up and stackable cell in order to make a convection battery large enough for electric vehicles and also further improvements on the capacity fade of sulfur cathodes for lithium-sulfur batteries.

                The development of a scaled-up flow-permeable electrode while maximizing active material loadings was a major result of this project. A method was developed to maintain a higher degree of active material loading, while still maintaining permeability to electrolyte flow.  Cell design also played an important role in developing a scalable and stackable battery cell. The cell was designed to reduce excessive empty space within the cell, to reduce overall weight, and to maintain proper flow throughout the system.

                The other major result of this project was reduced fade in sulfur cathodes. A method was developed to minimize the dissolution of active intermediates during cycling
